Welcome to the White House! Feel free to take the Color Tour or Regular Tour.
Hello! Welcome to White House! Feel free to ask about our available tours or our available quizzes. You can also ask to leave feedback at any point during your tour.

 Available tours include the Color Tour and the Regular Tour

The Regular Tour will take you through the China Room, State Dining Room,Library, Vermeil Room, and the Oval Office. In order to move between rooms, ask to go to the next room to go forwards a room, or ask to go the previous room to go back a room. Hope you enjoy!

Located on the Ground Floor, this room has been used since 1917 as exhibition space for White House ceramics, glass, and silver. The painting of First Lady Grace Coolidge has hung in the China Room since 1952. Ask about the objects in the room!

qna.a:
The State Dining Room, the second largest room in the White House, is the setting for State Dinners, when a head of state is entertained, as well as for
"official dinners," when the guest of honor is prime minister, ambassador, or
private citizen. Ask about the objects in the room!

qna.a: The Library is located on the Ground Floor of the White House. Although libraries have been a mainstay in the White House since the Millard Fillmore administration, it was not until 1935 that President Franklin D. Roosevelt formally designated a room for the library. The Library boasts thousands of books and the room occasionally serves as the backdrop for meetings, interviews, or televised speeches. Ask about the objects in the room!
Sorry, there are currently no objects in this room
q: What are the objects in the room?
What are the objects in the Library

qna.a: The Vermeil Room, located on the Ground Floor of the Executive Mansion, houses the extensive collection of vermeil, or gilded silver, that was bequeathed by Margaret Thompson Biddle to the White House in 1957. First Lady Mamie Eisenhower was the first to display the newly acquired vermeil collection in the room and today the room also displays several portraits of first ladies of the twentieth century. Ask about the objects in the room!

qna.a:
Americans have developed a sentimental attachment to the Oval Office. Television broadcasts from the Oval Office, such as President Reagan's speech following the Challenger explosion, have left a lasting impressions in the minds of Americans.
 Ask about the objects in the room!

qna.a: Ask about the desk!

qna.a: Many presidents have used the Resolute Desk in the Oval Office. It was made from the timbers of HMS Resolute, an abandoned British ship discovered by an American vessel and returned to the Queen of England. When the ship was retired, Queen Victoria commissioned the desk and presented to President Rutherford Hayes in 1880.

The Color Tour will take you through the Blue Room, the Green Room, and the Red Room.In order to move between rooms, ask to go to the next room to go forwards a room, or ask to go the previous room to go back a room. Hope you enjoy!

The blue and gold silk used for the walls and the curtains were added in 1952 and the chairs are part of the Bellangé suite. The Blue Room is located on the State Floor of the Executive Mansion. The oval parlor has been known as Blue Room since Martin Van Buren’s 1837 redecoration. The room is often used for receptions, photo opportunities, and during the holiday season is home to the official White House Christmas Tree. Ask about the objects in the room!
q: Let's go to the Blue Room
Take me to the Blue Room

qna.a: Ask about the Christmas Tree!
q: What are the objects in the room?
What are the objects in the blue room

qna.a: According to Wikipedia: The White House Christmas Tree, also known as the Blue Room Christmas Tree, is the official indoor Christmas tree at the residence of the President of the United States, the White House. The first indoor Christmas tree was installed in the White House sometime in the 19th century (there are varying claims as to the exact year) and since 1961 the tree has had a themed motif at the discretion of the First Lady of the United States.
q: tell me about the blue room christmas tree
tell me about the christmas tree

qna.a:
The Green Room, the first of the State Rooms to be named for the color of its textiles, is furnished in the late Federal style popular when the White House was first occupied. 

The least formal of the state parlors, the Green Room provides a serene setting for small gatherings, interviews, teas, and social activities. Ask about the objects in the room!
q: Let's go to the Green Room
Take me to the Green Room

qna.a: Ask about the Mantel Clock!
q: What are the objects in the room?
What are the objects in the green room

qna.qid: Green Room French Empire Mantel Clock
qna.a: The Green Room has a Mantel Clock: According to Wikipedia, A French Empire-style mantel clock is a type of elaborately decorated mantel clock made in France during the Napoleonic Empire between 1804–1814/15, although the timekeepers manufactured throughout the Bourbon Restoration (1814/1815–1830) are also included within this art movement since they share subject, decorative elements, shapes and style

The Red Room was the last of the state parlors to be named for a color, boldly decorated with red fabrics first in 1845, by James K. Polk. Today the furnishings are in the American "Empire" or
"Grecian" style that was popular in the early nineteenth century.
 Ask about the objects in the room!

qna.a: Ask about the Sofa!
q: What are the objects in the room?

qna.a: This Grecian style sofa with gilded and scrolled arms and feet was made by an unknown New York cabinetmaker influenced by English Regency and French Empire forms. The sofa became part of the White House Collection in 1961.
